metadata.title: Kaplan Meier Mistakes. Kaplan Meier analysis is often misused… | by Tomas Bencomo | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: A patient’s prognosis refers to the risk of future medical outcomes such as surgery complications, tumor recurrence, or death. Prognostic factor research is the study of information that can predict…

all_paragraphs: A patient’s prognosis refers to the risk of future medical outcomes such as surgery complications, tumor recurrence, or death. Prognostic factor research is the study of information that can predict a patient’s prognosis¹. Validated prognostic factors are an important part of translational research used to inform clinical decision-making, hypothesize about disease mechanisms, and stratify patients for personalized medicine².

Survival data is used to study prognostic factors, and Kaplan Meier analysis is often used due to it’s assumed ease of use. Unfortunately, some researchers misunderstand Kaplan Meier analysis and use it incorrectly, creating statistical problems with their analysis and potentially causing medical errors.

The goal of this article is to highlight common Kaplan Meier errors in a manner accessible to researchers without a deep background in statistics. Although I’d prefer to write about how to properly analyze survival data, that hope is near impossible. Survival analysis is a complex area with entire textbooks devoted to the topic. Instead, my hope is that after reading this post you’ll be able to spot common mistakes, avoid these mistakes in your own research, and improve your ability to critique prognostic factor research.

Before we talk about problems with Kaplan Meier analysis, what exactly is Kaplan Meier? The Kaplan Meier estimator is a statistical method used to estimate the probability of survival over time. This estimate is important because it describes the general prognosis of a disease — useful information to help patients and physicians discuss healthcare plans. Kaplan Meier plots visualize the probability a patient survives a certain amount of time. Figure 1 plots NCCTG cohort lung cancer survival probabilities. The median survival time, the amount of time at which 50% of patients are still alive, is about 300 days. The light red bands on either side of the curve are the 95% confidence intervals, indicating it is likely that the true survival probability is somewhere within the red area. Figure 1 is the most general assessment of risk we can make without any additional information about a patient. It is the probability of survival for all individuals in the NCCTG cohort.

Although Figure 1 gives a good summary about the general prognosis for lung cancer patients, we know there are a host of factors that contribute to differential survival times. With additional information we can give more accurate survival estimates to individual patients. The NCCTG dataset includes the sex of each patient, letting us estimate the probability of survival separately for males and females like in Figure 2.

Figure 2 shows female patients survived longer than their male counterparts. You may notice the curve from Figure 1 appears centered between the curves in Figure 2. This is no coincidence; without any patient information, the overall estimate in Figure 1 averaged the survival probabilities between males and females.

Notice the explanation of Kaplan Meier didn’t mention testing for a survival difference. That’s because the Kaplan Meier estimator only estimates survival probabilities. It doesn’t compare them. To make inferences about these survival probabilities we need the log-rank test.

The log-rank test is a hypothesis test that compares the survival probabilities between two groups. It computes a p-value indicating the compatibility between the data and the null hypothesis contingent on all of the test’s assumptions being correct³. Hypothesis testing is useful when we have a sample of data from a larger population and we want to make statements about the population as a whole. Because we don’t have measurements for every lung cancer patient, there is uncertainty surrounding our sample of patients. Statistical testing helps us navigate this uncertainty by providing a measure of evidence for statements about the population. Although statistical testing can help us make inferences (decisions) about the general population, testing isn’t without its caveats. P-values are notoriously difficult to interpret, and many statisticians have called for an end to statistical significance, the practice of labeling a finding as significant if the p-value is less than .05. Check out this commentary in Nature to learn more about the limitations of p-values.

Now let’s see a brief example of the log-rank test. We’ve collected data on lung cancer patients from the NCCTG study and we want to make an inference about sex specific survival rates. First, we hypothesize that there exists a survival difference between male and female patients with lung cancer. The null hypothesis is that no survival difference exists between males and females. The alternative hypothesis is that a survival difference does exist. We then use statistical software to compute a p-value for the log-rank test. The test produces a p-value of .001, suggesting that there is a survival difference between males and females in the general lung cancer population.

From here on I’ll use the phrase Kaplan Meier analysis to mean using Kaplan Meier plots and the log-rank test to analyze survival differences. The rest of this article will examine mistakes researchers make when they use Kaplan Meier to analyze survival data.

Binary, categorical, and continuous variables are prevalent in medical studies. Binary variables consist of only two values such as treatment vs no treatment. Categorical variables are similar to binary variables but with more than two choices like placebo vs drug A vs. drug B. Continuous variables are numeric variables such as age, gene expression, blood pressure, and tumor size. These variables can take on infinitely many values, depending on how precisely the variable is measured. Because continuous variables can take on infinite values, there are no groups like in binary or categorical variables.

Researchers trying to analyze continuous variables with Kaplan Meier analysis will immediately encounter problems: the log-rank test only compares survival between groups. How do we analyze a variable without any groups? To use the log-rank test, the continuous variable must somehow be split into groups. The most common approach is to dichotomize the variable so that values are classified as low or high. The median cutpoint is often used to separate the low and high groups (Figure 3).

Some studies use “optimal” cutpoints to dichotomize continuous variables. Optimal cutpoints are defined as the value that creates the largest survival separation between groups, yielding the smallest p-values. To identify optimal cutpoints, it’s common to examine all possible values and choose the cutpoint that produces the smallest p-value. This approach is problematic because testing every cutpoint creates a multiple testing problem. Testing so many different cutpoints exaggerates p-values and greatly increases the chance of false positives. Worse, optimal cutpoints are usually dataset dependent, meaning the cutpoint found in one study is unlikely to be the same in other studies⁴⁻¹¹. Researchers should avoid using optimal cutpoints to dichotomize continuous variables.

Even if researchers avoid “optimal” cutpoints and use the median, dichotomization causes loss of statistical power and makes poor assumptions about the distribution of risk. Statistical power is the probability that, assuming the effect we’re looking for exists, our statistical test detects it. Power is determined by the number of samples, the variability of the data, and the statistical method used (some methods are more efficient than others). High power is crucial for making scientific discoveries because low powered studies will often miss important effects. Researchers should be using methods that maximize statistical power.

Dichotomizing continuous variables decreases power by forcing all measurements to take on a simple yes or no value. Using binary variables instead of continuous variables can triple the number of samples needed to detect an effect¹¹. Using methods with low statistical power is both cost prohibitive and unethical because more patients will be needed than necessary (Figure 4). Methods that don’t dichotomize, like Cox regression, should be used instead.

Dichotomization also makes poor assumptions about the distribution of risk among patients⁴. For example, consider age as a prognostic factor for myocardial infarction (MI). Older age is usually associated with a greater risk of MI. Using a median age of 65, all patients less than 65 years old would be classified as young and patients over 65 are classified as old. This dichotomization assumes all young patients have the same risk of MI. It also assumes all old patients have the same, higher risk of MI than younger patients (Figure 5). This assumption is clearly wrong as a 64-year-old man is much more likely to have a heart attack than a 40-year-old. There’s no reason a 64-year-old should be in the same risk group as a 40-year-old; no biological switch suddenly turns on when we turn 65 that drastically increases our risk of a heart attack from when we are 64.

Although some biological variables do display a stepwise action mechanism, where nothing happens until a certain value is reached — think the 55mV action potential in neurons to open ion gated channels — research suggests most physiological variables don’t follow such mechanisms⁹. Instead, risk changes gradually as the variable changes. Some variables even follow nonlinear trends (Figure 6). Continuous modeling methods like Cox regression can allow for these trends, considering the 40-year-old at similar risk to a 41-year-old instead of a 64-year-old.

Prognostic studies usually analyze multiple variables, also called covariates. It’s common to see studies analyze each variable independently as well as multiple variables together (Figure 7). Analyzing each variable independently is a univariable analysis while analyzing multiple variables together is called multivariable analysis.

Both methods of analysis are popular despite univariable models providing little information about a prognostic factor’s importance¹²⁻¹³. When multiple factors influence survival, a univariable analysis will overestimate or underestimate the prognostic effect because the analysis assumes the effects of multiple variables are attributable to the single variable being analyzed. This is called omitted-variable bias and explains why the univariable hazard ratios in Figure 7 are much larger than the multivariable hazard ratios. Multivariable models are needed to adjust for multiple prognostic factors, decreasing omitted-variable bias and disentangling the effects of each variable on survival.

Kaplan Meier is a univariable method. This means Kaplan Meier results are easily biased, exaggerating prognostic importance or missing the signal entirely. Analyzing a single continuous marker in a univariable Cox regression is another example of a univariable analysis and will produce uninformative results. Multivariable methods that can adjust for multiple variables, like Cox regression, should be used instead¹².

Many studies will claim a new biomarker is prognostic solely from a univariable Kaplan Meier analysis. While the biomarker may be prognostic, this is very hard to prove from univariable analyses alone. At a minimum the variable should be analyzed in a Cox model with other basic prognostic factors. Information like age and sex are often available and prognostic of many diseases, serving as good baseline variables to adjust for. Although it’s not possible to adjust for every potential variable, performing a literature review and talking with clinicians are good ways to identify strong prognostic factors that can have a major impact on the analysis. If the signal still holds in the multivariable analysis, there may be hope for the new biomarker.

While showing a small p-value in a multivariable model is the bare minimum to suggest a marker has prognostic value, there are more rigorous methods to evaluate prognostic factor importance¹⁴. Because many prognostic factors already exist, researchers should investigate the added value of new prognostic factors, quantifying how much new markers improve predictions.

There are many ways to quantify how much information is added by a new prognostic marker. The area under the ROC curve (AUC-ROC), the Likelihood Ratio Test, and R² are common metrics to measure predictive performance¹³⁻¹⁵. Although it’s beyond the scope of this post to discuss the pros and cons for each metric, the takeaway is that researchers must demonstrate the added value of their new marker.

After the added value has been quantified, it’s critical to evaluate the costs associated with this added value. Not all biomarkers are created equal, and some markers can provide substantially more information than others. Depending on the disease, classic clinical labs can provide substantially more information than genetic markers or healthcare records. It’s important to understand that each of these markers has a different cost. More expensive tests like genetic markers may need to provide more information than cheaper alternatives to justify their cost. Only physicians and patients can decide if the added information is worth the added cost, so it is crucial that prognostic studies rigorously quantify added value.

There are many ways to incorrectly analyze survival data. Researchers should avoid dichotomizing continuous variables, use multivariable models, and quantify the added value of new prognostic markers. Following these guidelines can lower our tolerance for poor quality studies and improve future research, leading to improvements in patient care.

If you want to learn more about survival analysis methods like Cox regression, check out my talk on best practices for survival analysis, which introduces statistical concepts and considerations that everyone doing survival analysis should know about.
[1] R. Riley et al, Prognosis Research Strategy (PROGRESS) 2: Prognostic Factor Research (2013), PLOS Medicine
[2] A. Hingorani et al, Prognosis research strategy (PROGRESS) 4: Stratified medicine research (2013), BMJ
[3] S. Greenland et al, Statistical tests, P values, confidence intervals, and power: A guide to misinterpretations (2016), European Journal of Epidemiology
[4] C. Bennette et al, Against quantiles: Categorization of continuous variables in epidemiologic research, and its discontents (2012), BMC Medical Research Methodology
[5] D. Altman, Dangers of Using “Optimal” Cutpoints in the Evaluation of Prognostic Factors (1994), JNCI: Journal of the National Cancer Institute
[6] K. Metze, Dichotomization of continuous data — A pitfall in prognostic factor studies (2008), Pathology — Research and Practice
[7] P. Royston et al, Dichotomizing continuous predictors in multiple regression: A bad idea (2006), Statistics in Medicine
[8] N. Dawson et al, Dichotomizing Continuous Variables in Statistical Analysis: A Practice to Avoid (2012), Medical Decision Making

[9] A. Giannoni et al, Do Optimal Prognostic Thresholds in Continuous Physiological Variables Really Exist? Analysis of Origin of Apparent Thresholds, with Systematic Review for Peak Oxygen Consumption, Ejection Fraction and BNP (2014), PLOS ONE
[10] D. Altman, PROBLEMS IN DICHOTOMIZING CONTINUOUS VARLABLES(1994), American Journal of Epidemiology
[11] D. Altman, P. Royston, The cost of dichotomising continuous variables (2006), BMJ : British Medical Journal
[12] K. Moons, Criteria for Scientific Evaluation of Novel Markers: A Perspective(2010), Clinical Chemistry
[13] E. Steyerberg et al, Assessing the incremental value of diagnostic and prognostic markers: A review and illustration (2012), European Journal of Clinical Investigation
[14] M. Pencina et al, Evaluating the added predictive ability of a new marker: From area under the ROC curve to reclassification and beyond (2008), Statistics in Medicine
[15] E. Steyerberg et al, Prognosis Research Strategy (PROGRESS) 3: Prognostic Model Research (2013), PLOS Medicine
Biomedical informatics student studying precision medicine and cancer biology. Interested in machine learning, bioinformatics, and medicine.
